utterances: And after the blog, can I ask you if there was one thing that you were delighted to get back to at the end of the project?
The laundry machine.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I was delighted to get back to the laundry machine.

But I should say that during the project, the thing that I was most delighted about is that I think that it - I think Michelle would agree that it made us much better parents because as we gave up so many screens and so many consumer distractions, it taught us that we could spend a lot more time having fun with our little girl.
And that kind of just continues for us.
And I think we're both very grateful for that.
And, Michelle, people who see the movie will want to know, did you go back and buy that bag at the end of the year?
I did not.
No. I did not buy that bag.
I didn't need one because I already had a bag.
As was pointed out.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Thank you both very much.
And good luck with the project and good luck with the film.
Thank you.
Thank you, Neal.
Colin Beavan joined us from Minnesota Public Radio in St. Paul.
He's a writer, blogger, and the subject of the film, ""No Impact Man,"" also a book.
Michelle Conlin with us from our bureau in New York.
She's the - also a subject to the film and a senior writer at BusinessWeek magazine.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR.
We'll see you again on Monday.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Start them up.
The AARP-eligible Rolling Stones begin another North American tour this Sunday at Boston's Fenway Park.
The show's officially sold out but tickets are going for as much as $1,800 on the Internet.
Commentator Clarence Page ponders why people keep shelling out like that to see the Stones roll on.
As an aging baby boomer, I find it very telling that the hottest-selling rock concert tour of this summer is a group of senior citizens.
Yes, the Rolling Stones are back, doing something their leader said he would never do, still performing ""Jumpin' Jack Flash"" into his elder years.
(Soundbite of ""Jumpin' Jack Flash"")
(Singing)
But it's all right.
I'm Jumpin' Jack Flash, it's a gas!
Gas!
Gas!
Mick Jagger is 62, and lead guitarist Keith Richards is 61.
Despite some wild years that could kill a horse, it's particularly significant that there has not been more creative energy in rock, the music of youthful rebellion, to push geezer rockers aside.
The music press says rock has hit hard times.
As a headline blared in the March 24 Rolling Stone magazine, which, of course, is no relation to the band, Rock Radio No Longer Rolling.
In the past year, leading rock radio stations in Philadelphia, Miami, San Jose, Houston and Washington, DC, have switched to other formats, like hip-hop or the new urban Hispanic sounds.
Rock CD sales have been struggling, with new rock CDs barely holding their own against the golden oldies.
You might remember a couple of years ago when all 10 of the top performers on the Billboard music sales charts were black artists.
It was the first time that happened in Billboard's 50-year history.
And people noticed.
(Soundbite of ""Baby Boy"")
(Singing) Baby boy, you stay on my mind.
You fulfill my fantasy.
(Singing) Come on, girl, let me ...(unintelligible).
(Singing) I think about you all the time.
I see you in my dreams.
(Singing) ...(Unintelligible).
The last upsurge in creative rock energy may have died with Kurt Cobain's suicide 11 years ago.
That moment left today's urban sound as the new engine of music creativity.
If so, history is only repeating itself.
The Stones openly borrowed black music sounds to create their own, like other white artists have from Elvis to Eminem.
They couldn't get `no satisfaction' otherwise.
(Soundbite of ""(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction"")
(Singing) I can't get no satisfaction.
Scott Wilson, in the Washington Post, suggested that the Iran threat may help these talks on the theory of the enemy of my enemy.
Sunni Muslims are very worried about Iran - almost as worried as Israel is.
And that could create some pressure to get somewhere.
So to ever be completely optimistic or even very optimistic in Mideast talks is foolish, but I think there's a real potential here.
So the Rolling Stones rock on while we wait to see what new will come out of the music laboratories of youth culture.
Who knows?

Unless another Beatles is just around the corner, rock as we know it may well be on its way to semi-cult status, followed by true-believer aficionados in the way jazz, bluegrass or the blues survives outside the mainstream they helped to create.
For new energy, pop music culture seems to be looking, once again, back to black music, and, to some degree, the emerging sounds of Hispanic hop and Afro-Pop, world music.
(Soundbite of music)
The world is shrinking in ways presaged by the British invasion of the '60s, the invasion that brought America the Rolling Stones, and they're still drawing huge crowds.
After all, this could be the last time.
(Soundbite of song)
(Singing) Well, this could be the last time.
This could be the last time, maybe the last time.
I don't know.
Clarence Page is a Washington-based syndicated columnist for the Chicago Tribune.
(Soundbite of song)
(Singing) Oh, no. Well, I'm sorry, girl, but I can't stay, feeling like I do today.
There's too much pain and too much sorrow.
This is NPR News.
During his eight years on ""Saturday Night Live,"" Bill Hader played everyone from Clint Eastwood to former Chinese President Hu Jintao.
But in his new HBO series ""Barry,"" Hader may have created his most challenging role - a hit man who wants to be an actor.
The show debuts Sunday, and NPR TV critic Eric Deggans has this review.
The best new comedy on television is also the darkest comedy on television.

I'm talking about ""Barry,"" a new series about an expert assassin who feels adrift in life until he follows a potential mark into an acting class and realizes his true calling, which doesn't go over too well with the guy who arranges all of Barry's jobs and handles his money, a fatherly figure named Fuchs played by Stephen Root.
Barry tries to convince Fuchs he can be a part-time hit man.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""BARRY"")
(As Barry) Well, you know, they told me a very small percentage of actors actually make a living acting.
So I just figured, you know, I'd do night hits or...
(As Fuchs) You want to have a hobby or something, you can take up painting.
Hitler painted.
John Wayne Gacy painted.
It never got in the way of what they were doing.
(As Barry) These are professional actors.
And they're the real deal.
And they say I got something.
(As Fuchs) You want to go out there and try to burn a guy and have him say, hey, there's that guy from the chicken commercial?
(As Barry) I don't know if I do commercials.
Barry's guide into acting is the class' teacher, Gene, played with ferocious flair by Henry Winkler.
In this role, Winkler is a delight as a potbellied poser who's so pretentious he can't see his mild-mannered student for who he really is.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""BARRY"")
(As Gene) Barry, you want to be an actor, you better get out of your own way.
(As Barry) OK.
(As Gene) Life is about taking a risk, making the unsafe choice.
All right, here's a little story just to illustrate.
I once auditioned for the guy that robbed the house on ""Full House."" And I carried a loaded Beretta with me into the audition just to feel the weight of it.
